skill.name: histolab
skill.description: Digital pathology image processing toolkit for whole slide images (WSI). Use this skill when working with histopathology slides, processing H&E or IHC stained tissue images, extracting tiles from gigapixel pathology images, detecting tissue regions, segmenting tissue masks, or preparing datasets for computational pathology deep learning pipelines. Applies to WSI formats (SVS, TIFF, NDPI), tile-based analysis, and histological image preprocessing workflows.

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing markdown files about the Histolab Python library. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or file system access beyond reading its own documentation files. All content describes legitimate digital pathology image processing operations.

content.value_statement: Digital pathology workflows require processing gigapixel whole slide images for computational analysis. This skill provides comprehensive guidance for extracting tiles, detecting tissue regions, and preparing datasets for deep learning pipelines in histopathology research.
actual_capabilities: Load and inspect whole slide images in SVS, TIFF, and NDPI formats
Extract tiles from gigapixel images using random, grid, or score-based strategies
Detect and segment tissue regions using automated mask generation
Apply image filters for stain deconvolution and contrast enhancement
Generate tissue masks to filter background and artifacts
Visualize slides, masks, and tile locations for quality assessment
limitations: Does not perform diagnosis or clinical analysis - provides data preparation only
Requires pre-installed histolab Python library for actual processing
Memory intensive for very large slides - requires appropriate hardware

output_examples.input: Extract 50 random tiles from my prostate tissue slide
output: Configure RandomTiler with tile size 512x512, 50 tiles, level 0, seed 42, check tissue enabled with 80 percent threshold
Apply TissueMask or BiggestTissueBoxMask to define extraction region
Preview tile locations with locate_tiles() before extraction
Tiles saved to processed_path directory with coordinates and metadata

best_practices: Always preview tile locations with locate_tiles() before extraction to verify configuration
Choose appropriate tissue mask type - TissueMask for multiple sections, BiggestTissueBoxMask for single main section
Match extraction pyramid level to analysis resolution requirements for optimal performance
anti_patterns: Do not extract at level 0 for initial exploration - use higher levels for faster preview
Do not skip tissue percentage filtering - expect many background tiles without it
Do not ignore slide properties - always verify dimensions and magnification before processing

faq.question: What WSI formats are supported?
faq.answer: Histolab supports SVS, TIFF, NDPI, and other formats compatible with OpenSlide library.

faq.question: How large can the slides be?
faq.answer: Slides can be gigapixel size. Level 0 processing requires significant RAM. Use level 1 or 2 for large slides.

faq.question: How does tile extraction integrate with existing code?
faq.answer: Histolab provides Python classes that can be imported and used in any Python script or notebook workflow.

faq.question: Is patient data handled safely?
faq.answer: All processing is local. Histolab does not transmit data. Ensure proper data handling per institutional policies.

faq.question: Extraction produces no tiles - what is wrong?
faq.answer: Lower tissue_percent threshold, verify slide contains tissue using thumbnail, check extraction_mask captures tissue regions.

faq.question: How does this compare to other pathology tools?
faq.answer: Histolab focuses on tile extraction and preprocessing. It integrates with other tools like OpenSlide for raw image access.
